ThingDef.label: deinotherium
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant mammals, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

"Deinotherium" means "terrible beast". It's a unique cousin to mammoths and mastodons, equipped with downward curving tusks on the lower jaw.
Very short-tempered and incredibly dangerous when angered.

ThingDef.label: aurochs
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant mammals, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

The ancestor of domestic cattle, the aurochs, was to modern cows what wolves are to dogs.
Larger, tougher, faster, but producing less resources and eating more than today's cattle.

ThingDef.label: megalochelys
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant reptiles, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

The largest tortoise of all time.
There aren't many predators that pose a threat to megalochelys, thanks to its thick and hard as rock shell. The ones that attempt to attack it anyway, will have to be prepared to deal with its surprisingly powerful bite.

ThingDef.label: palaeeudyptes
ThingDef.description: Long extinct giant birds, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.\n\nThe biggest penguin in history. While it's clearly best fitted for hunting fish, palaeeudyptes won't hesitate to take advantage of its huge size, and will attempt to hunt other vertebrates that are smaller than itself.

ThingDef.label: josephoartigasia
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant mammals, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

The largest rodent of all time, josephoartigasia, resembles a gigantic capybara or pacarana, but in a few regards it appears to be closer to today's hippopotamuses.
It is not a very good runner, and to compensate for that, it sports huge incisors that could prove very dangerous to lesser predators.

ThingDef.label: gigantophis
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant reptiles, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

The second biggest snake in history, thought to have been the largest until the discovery of titanoboa.
It much prefers hunting big animals as they're easier to smell out.

ThingDef.label: meganeura
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant arthropods, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

The biggest flying insect to ever exist, meganeura, just like modern dragonflies, is a highly specialised predator.
Swift and agile, it used to have no aerial competition, which was one of the reasons why it had evolved to be so gigantic.

ThingDef.label: zygolophodon
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant mammals, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

One of the mastodons, and owner of some of the longest tusks in history.
While more primitive than mammoths, it's bigger, tougher, and more powerful than most of them. It is also heavier than some sauropod dinosaurs.

ThingDef.label: platybelodon
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant mammals, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

Very unique kind of proboscideans, which, due to the shape of their two lower teeth is popularly known as "shovel tuskers".
It grasps tree branches with its trunk and rubs them against the lower teeth to cut them off. The "tusk shovel" is also used by platybelodons to strip bark from trees.

ThingDef.label: purussaurus
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant reptiles, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

Quite possibly, the largest crocodilian of all time, and also the biggest reptile to roam the Earth after the extinction of dinosaurs.
It is so massive that even giant ground sloths have a place on its menu.

ThingDef.label: uintatherium
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant mammals, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

A very primitive, giant cousin of rhinoceroses.
It is neither the most beautiful, nor the most intelligent animal in history, with its brain being merely the size of an orange, but it can make up for it with its strong back, which renders it a good partner for a journey.

ThingDef.label: pulmonoscorpius
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant arthropods, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

The biggest land scorpion to ever exist.
Pulmonoscorpius is a solitary predator capable of taking down creatures way larger than itself with its deadly venom. Its sting should be stayed away from at all costs.

ThingDef.label: dinopithecus
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant mammals, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

A gigantic species of baboons with an unusually prominent liking for meat.
They used to be the natural enemies of early humans, hunting them down more often than one could expect. It is possible that they could see modern humans as prey, too.

ThingDef.label: castoroides
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant mammals, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

Giant beavers, the largest to ever exist.
Its incisors aren't as well fitted for cutting wood as those of its modern equivalents, which is why it doesn't bother with constructing dams. This makes it so it will more often have to resort to either running from predators or attempting to fight them off, instead of simply hiding away from them.

ThingDef.label: enhydriodon
ThingDef.description:
Long extinct giant mammals, brought back to life as a part of the Megafauna Project.

The largest mustelid ever discovered. Enhydriodon is a bear-sized ancestor of modern otters, and a very dangerous predator that used to be a big threat to early humans.
Great swimmers, surprisingly swift on land.
